description.narrative: Tematiskt UNICEFstöd för arbete inom vatten, sanitet och hygien (WASH). Bidrar till barns och kvinnors överlevnad och utveckling. Detta beslut hör ihop med beslut.....................som beslutar om kompletterande medel från avräkningskonto 155037 efter delegering av outnyttjat afrikaanslag. Båda besluten kopplas till samma avtal, beredning och uppföljning. Besluten uppgår tillsammans till MSEK 800.

The overall objective of UNICEF in the area of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) is to contribute to to the realization of children's rights to survival and development through promotion of the sector and support to national programmes that increase equitable and sustainable access to, and use of, safe water and basic sanitation services, and promote improved hygiene.

UNICEF's WASH-specific strategy covers the period 2016-2030. The WASH Strategy's objectives are to achieve the first two targets of SDG 6 water and sanitation: 1. By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all: 2. By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations. Under the current new WASH strategy 2016-2030, UNICEF will focus on five results areas: water, sanitation, hygiene, WASH in institutions (schools and health care facilities) and WASH in emergencies.

sector.narrative: Water supply and sanitation - large systems

description.narrative: Over the period of the UNICEF Strategic Plan 2014–2017, more than 150 millionpeople benefited from improved water supplies as a result of UNICEF’s direct support.About two thirds of these individuals gained access to water as a result of humanitarianresponse in emergencies, and one third through development programming. Over thesame four-year period, UNICEF helped more than 70 million people gain access to basicsanitation in their homes, while improving WASH facilities and services in over 51,000schools and 5,000 health centres. The following results have been achieved within UNICEF WASH programmeduring the period of implementation years 2014-2017: Summary of results achieved during 2014: - 13.8 million people in 62 countries gained access to improved water supply,- 11.3 million people gained access to sanitation facilities,- 19,097 communities obtained certification as open defecation free (ODF),- built WASH facilities in 10,596 schools, and- built WASH facilities in 1,203 health centres. The following results have been achieved within UNICEF Emergency response duringthe first year of implementation (year 2014): - 18 million people were provided access to safe water supplies,- 4.4 million used adequate sanitation facilities,- 13 million practised appropriate handwashing,- 3.1 million children with WASH facilities in their schools and temporary learningenvironment, and - 1.7 million women and girls provided with menstrual hygiene management supplies asa result of UNICEF direct interventions and support in humanitarian situations. Summary of results achieved during 2015: - 14.1 million people in 83 countries gained access to improved water supply,- 12.1 million people in 84 countries gained access to sanitation facilities,- 23,316 communities obtained certification as open defecation free (ODF) in 47countries,- built WASH facilities in 25,876 schools in 87 countries, and- built WASH facilities in 733 health centres in 76 countries.The above results are due to direct support from UNICEF. In 2015, UNICEF responded directly in humanitarian situations in a total of 76countries. UNICEF also continued its leadership role in WASH emergency coordinationin 2015, and led or co-led the WASH Cluster in 66 countries. The following results have been achieved within UNICEF Emergency response duringthe second year of implementation (year 2015): - 25.5 million people were provided access to safe water supplies,- 6 million used adequate sanitation facilities,- 13.8 million practised appropriate handwashing (hygiene),- 4.1 million children with WASH facilities in their schools and temporary learningenvironment. -In 2015, UNICEF also continued to provide direct support to Menstrual HygieneManagement (MHM) programming in schools and communities, guiding standards andpolicy development, education campaigns and research. This includes MHM support inhumanitarian situations.-In 2015, UNICEF published 20 papers in peer-reviewed high-impact journals includingthe Lancet Global Health, the British Medical Journal and the American Journal ofTropical Medicine and Hygiene. Summary of results achieved during 2016: -UNICEF delivered results in WASH in 109 countries, through programmesmanaged by 660 professional staff of which the majority posted in sub-Saharan Africa - 10.5 million people gained access to improved water supply,- 10.2 million people gained access to sanitation facilities,- 33,798 communities obtained certification as open defecation free (ODF),- built WASH facilities in 7,138 schools in 71 countries, and- built WASH facilities in 1654 health centres in 44 countries. The following results have been achieved within UNICEF Emergency response duringthe third year of implementation (year 2016): -In 2016, UNICEF WASH responded directly in humanitarian situations in a total of 77countries. UNICEF also continued its leadership role in WASH emergency coordinationin 2016, and led or co-led the WASH Cluster in 72 countries.- 28.8 million people were provided access to safe water supplies,- 7.2 million used adequate sanitation facilities,- 15.8 million practised appropriate handwashing (hygiene),- 2.7 million children with WASH facilities in their schools and temporary learningenvironment. -UNICEF also continued to provide direct support to Menstrual HygieneManagement (MHM) programming in schools and communities, guiding standards andpolicy development, education campaigns and research. This includes MHM support inhumanitarian situations.- UNICEF published 28 papers in peer-reviewed journals. Summary of results during the fourth and final year of implementation (year 2017): -Unicef delivered results in WASH in 113 countries, through programmesmanaged by over 650 professional staff of which the majority posted in sub-SaharanAfrica. -12 million people gained access to improved water supply, 13 million people gained access to sanitation facilities,-over 50,000 communities obtain certification as open defecation free (ODF), WASH facilities in over 7,835 schools in 75 countries, and -built WASH facilities in 1.557 health centres in almost 50 countries. In 2017, UNICEF WASH responded directly in humanitarian situations in a total of 94countries. UNICEF also continued its leadership role in WASH emergency coordinationin 2017, and led or co-led the WASH Cluster in 69 countries. The following results have been achieved within UNICEF Emergency response during the fourth and final year of implementation (year 2017): -33 million people were provided access to safe watersupplies, 9 million used adequate sanitation facilities, 28 million practised appropriatehandwashing (hygiene), 2.4 million children with WASH facilities in their schools andtemporary learning environment. The above results are due to direct support fromUNICEF. Some unexpected results can include the imortant support that UNICEF has continued to provide direct support to Menstrual Hygiene Management (MHM) programming in schools and communities, guiding standards and policy development, education campaigns and research. This type of work has levereged interest in these areas by other organizations working within the WASH spectrum, but also within the health and education sectors. This has also included MHM support in humanitarian situations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
